body:
Git flip/flops on that one, if it is really sure you just misspelled something it will just run it for you:

```sh
$ git rease master
WARNING: You called a Git command named 'rease', which does not exist.
Continuing under the assumption that you meant 'rebase'
in 0.1 seconds automatically...
Current branch master is up to date.
```

I'm against keeping an ever growing list of rake tasks to check against especially since we could remove a task without remembering to remove it from the list. By shelling out with `--dry-run` we're guaranteeing that it is a valid task and available to the system. How would you feel if I took out the timeout and auto-run feature and just displayed a message instead (keeping in the system check to see if the command exists)?
